title: Opportunity Insights All Outcomes
description: This table reports predicted outcomes for children by four different spatial resolusions (census tract, county, community zone, and national level), race and gender. The data is organized long on different spatial resolusions and wide on race, gender and parent income percentile rank, so that there is exactly one row per tract, and a variable for each race/gender/parent income percentile rank combination. To protect privacy, a small amount of noise is added to each of the estimates; this noise is typically less than one-tenth the size of the standard error of the estimate itself. The standard errors reported below incorporate both sampling error and the noise that was added to the point estimates to protect privacy.  We provide the tract-level unconditional means as well as predictions at five percentiles of the parent national income distribution among parents with children in the same birth cohort (referred to as “[pctile]” in the codebook). In particular, we consider the 1st, 25th, 50th, 75th, and 100th percentiles.
creator: Opportunity Insights
subject: Demographics
Economic Stability
Employment
Education
Housing
Social and Community Context
methods_variables: Mean predicted outcome for children of a given race, gender, and with parents at a given percentile
Mean household income rank for parents of children of race and gender
Fraction of children with parents who have income below the national median for parents with children in the same birth cohort
Mean fraction of possible childhood years (up to age 23) children spent
Fraction of children who have a male claimer in the year they are linked to parents
Fraction of children who have a female claimer in the year they are linked to parents
Fraction incarcerated on April 1st, 2010
Mean percentile rank (relative to other children born in the same year) in the national distribution of household income measured as mean earnings in 2014-2015 for the baseline sample
Baseline kfr measure (2014-15 income) as defined above, but restricted to children who live in one of their childhood commuting zones in adulthood
Probability of reaching the top 1% of the national household income distribution (among children born in the same year) in 2014-15
Probability of reaching the top quintile of the national household income distribution (among children born in the same year) in 2014-15
Mean percentile rank (relative to other children in the same year) in the national distribution of household income measured at age 24, 26, and 29
Mean percentile rank (relative to other children born in the same year) in the national distribution of individual income measured as mean earnings in 2014-2015 for the baseline sample
Baseline kir measure (2014-15 income) as defined above, but restricted to children who live in one of their childhood commuting zones in adulthood
Probability of reaching the top 1% of the national individual income distribution (among children born in the same year) in 2014-15
Probability of reaching the top quintile of the national individual income distribution (among children born in the same year) in 2014-15
Mean percentile rank (relative to other children in the same year) in the national distribution of individual income measured at age 24, 26, and 29
Fraction of children who grew up in a given tract and end up living in a tract with a poverty rate of less than 10% (according to tract-level Census 2000 data) in adulthood
Fraction of children who file their federal income tax return as “married filing jointly” or “married filing separately” in 2015
Fraction of children who file their federal income tax return as “married filing jointly” or “married filing separate” at age 26, 29, and 32
Mean individual income rank in 2014-15 for the spouses of children who grew up in the given tract
Fraction of children who live in one of their childhood commuting zones in adulthood
Fraction of children who live at the same address as their parents in 2015
Fraction of individuals who live in one of their childhood Census tracts in adulthood
Fraction of women who grew up in the given tract who ever claimed a child born when they were between the ages of 13 and 19 as a dependent
Fraction of children claimed by two people in the year they are linked to parents
Fraction of children with positive W-2 earnings in 2015
Fraction of children with positive W-2 earnings at age 24, 26, 29, and 32
Baseline kfr measure (2014-15 income) defined above, but restricted to children whose mothers immigrated to the United States
Baseline kfr measure (2014-15 income) defined above, but restricted to children whose mothers were born in the United States
Baseline kir measure (2014-15 income) defined above, but restricted to children whose mothers immigrated to the United States
Baseline kir measure (2014-15 income) defined above, but restricted to children whose mothers were born in the United States
data_variables: Number of children of race and gender
Count of children under 18 of race and gender
Mean outcome for children of race and gender
Fraction of children who have a four-year college degree (among children who received ACS or 2000 Census long form at age 25+)
Fraction of children who have at least a community college degree (among children who received the ACS or the 2000 Census long form at age 25+)
Fraction of children who have a graduate degree (among children who received the ACS or 2000 long form at age 30+)
Mean weekly hours child worked in the 12 months before they were surveyed (among children who received ACS at age 30+)
Fraction of children who completed high school or obtained a GED (among children who received the ACS or 2000 long form at age 19+)
Fraction of children with positive hours worked in the 12 months before being surveyed (among children who received the ACS at age 30+)

Fraction of children having at least some college experience (among children who received the ACS or 2000 long form at age 25+)
Mean individual income rank in 2014-15 for the spouses of children who grew up in the given tract
